format: This data frame contains the following columns:

parameters.education: Percentage of occupational incumbents in 1950 who were high school graduates (which, were we cynical, we would say is roughly equivalent to a PhD in 2017)
parameters.income: Percentage of occupational incumbents in the 1950 US Census who earned $3,500 or more per year (about $36,000 in 2017 US dollars).
parameters.prestige: Percentage of respondents in a social survey who rated the occupation as “good” or better in prestige

title: Duncan's Occupational Prestige Data
description:
Description
The Duncan data frame has 45 rows and 4 columns.
Data on the prestige and other characteristics of 45 U. S. occupations in 1950.
reference:
Duncan, O. D. (1961)
A socioeconomic index for all occupations.
In Reiss, A. J., Jr. (Ed.)
Occupations and Social Status. Free Press
[Table VI-1].
